concepts.name: Sleep quality
concepts.description: A multidimensional measure of sleep depth, continuity, and restoration, serving as the primary independent variable in the study. It directly correlates with cognitive outcomes and is influenced by internal/external factors.

concepts.name: Cognitive functioning
concepts.description: The collective mental processes including attention, memory, and emotional regulation, measured as the dependent variable. The study establishes its impairment as a key consequence of poor sleep quality.

concepts.name: Attention duration
concepts.description: The sustained focus capacity during cognitive tasks, significantly shortened by poor sleep quality. Represents a core component of executive function affected by sleep disruption.

concepts.name: Memory consolidation
concepts.description: The neural process of stabilizing and integrating newly acquired information into long-term memory, impaired by inadequate sleep quality. Critical for learning and knowledge retention.

concepts.name: Emotional regulation
concepts.description: The ability to manage and respond to emotional stimuli, destabilized by poor sleep quality. Linked to increased emotional reactivity and reduced stress resilience.

concepts.name: Confounding variables
concepts.description: Uncontrolled factors (e.g., diet, exercise) that may influence both sleep quality and cognitive outcomes, limiting causal inference in the study design. Highlighted as a key limitation.

concepts.name: Recall bias
concepts.description: Systematic error in self-reported data due to inaccurate memory of past sleep patterns or cognitive performance. Identified as a limitation affecting data reliability.

concepts.name: Cross-sectional design
concepts.description: Research approach collecting data at a single timepoint, preventing causal inference between sleep quality and cognitive outcomes. Explicitly noted as a study limitation.

methods.name: Mixed-methods design
methods.description: Integration of quantitative (self-report, physiological data) and qualitative approaches to comprehensively assess sleep-cognition relationships. Combines subjective experiences with objective measurements.

methods.name: Self-report questionnaires
methods.description: Standardized surveys (e.g., Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index) used to assess subjective sleep quality and daily cognitive experiences. Administered to capture participant-perceived sleep patterns and functional impacts.

methods.name: Standardized cognitive testing
methods.description: Validated neuropsychological batteries (e.g., Stroop test, Rey Auditory Verbal Learning Test) administered to objectively measure attention, memory, and executive function. Provides quantifiable cognitive performance metrics.

methods.name: Wearable physiological monitoring
methods.description: Use of actigraphy or sleep trackers to collect objective sleep data (e.g., sleep duration, fragmentation, REM cycles). Complements self-reports with continuous physiological metrics.
